data.title: Pwntools
data.desc: A set of tools used extensively for CTFs

data.title: Cutter
data.desc: A GUI overlay for radare2, excellent for reverse engineering.

data.title: Ghidra
data.desc: A reverse engineering tool developed by the NSA.

data.title: Binwalk
data.desc: A very helpful forensics and reverse engineering tool for finding markers for what kinds of files are contained in a file.

data.title: Stegosuite
data.desc: Tool for hiding information in image files.

data.title: Linux Subsystem For Windows
data.desc: A good tool for getting a linux terminal in any Windows 10 machine

data.title: Kali Linux
data.desc: A linux build designed for information security and penetration testing with lots of tools already installed.

data.title: AwesomeCTF
data.desc: A long list of resources, guides, and CTFs for practice.

data.title: CTF101
data.desc: A wiki and guidebook that serves as a good introduction to the categories in CTFs.

data.title: CTF Wiki
data.desc: Another wiki for helpful CTF information.

data.title: CTF Field Guide
data.desc: A few useful guides for some of the more basic skills needed in CTFs.

data.title: String Format Vulnerabilities
data.desc: An excellent written guide to string vulnerabilities.

data.title: LiveOverflow
data.desc: A guy who started a youtube channel devoted to hacking/pen testing/CTFs, now a great site and resource for learning about infosec skills

data.title: Network Academy
data.desc: Created by Cisco, this has a lot of courses in various areas of information security.

data.title: Penetration Testing Practice Lab
data.desc: A looong list of sites and machines to practice penetration testing.

data.title: HackTheBox
data.desc: A site known for the challenge it provides

data.title: PicoCTF
data.desc: The site we use to practice in our workshops.  A beginner friendly CTF site, and the largest CTF in the world

data.title: CTFLearn
data.desc: A long list of challenges and problems to try

data.title: Practice CTF List
data.desc: a list of sites that host practice CTF challenges

data.title: HackMe
data.desc: CTF practice problems

data.title: RootMe
data.desc: CTF practice problems

data.title: OverTheWire
data.desc: Network and computer security challenges.

data.title: CTFtime
data.desc: Create a profile and track your progress as you compete in CTFs.  It also tracks upcoming CTFs, teams, and has an archive of past CTFs and writeups for many previous CTFs.

data.title: Major League Cyber
data.desc: Another great site for creating a profile and tracking your progress as you compete in CTFS.

data.title: WeChall
data.desc: Another tracking site for CTFs.

data.title: Guide to x86 Assembly
data.desc: A good overall guide to assembly, but not an easy or accessible read!

data.title: Jump Guide
data.desc: A list of the jump codes for AT&T assembly.

data.title: X86 Assembly Wiki
data.desc: A good book/resource for instructions.

data.title: File Signatures List
data.desc: A good list of the hex signatures

data.title: HackerOne
data.desc: A site dedicated to providing bug bounties for security vulnerabilities found in popular programming languages.

data.title: Learn Cryptography
data.desc: A good site for learning cryptography from the ground up

data.title: Cryptopals
data.desc: A site with a lot of hands on practice for learning basic cryptography

data.title: LiveOverflow
data.desc: The youtube side of LiveOverflow.com

data.title: John Hammond
data.desc: Some really great beginner guides for CTFs.  John does a great job at taking his time to explain what is happening and how it works.
